message_1: Suppose that $f(z)$ is an entire function such that $|f(z)|\leq 5|z|^3$ for all $z\in\mathbb{C}$. Prove that $f(z)$ is a polynomial of degree at most $3$.
message_2:
To prove that $f(z)$ is a polynomial of degree at most $3$, we will use the Cauchy's estimates for the derivatives of an entire function.

Let $R > 0$ be an arbitrary positive real number and let $z_0 \in \mathbb{C}$. Consider the circle $|z - z_0| = R$. By Cauchy's integral formula, we have

$$f^{(n)}(z_0) = \frac{n!}{2\pi i} \oint_{|z-z_0|=R} \frac{f(z)}{(z-z_0)^{n+1}} dz$$

for all non-negative integers $n$. Taking the absolute value of both sides, we get

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \frac{n!}{2\pi} \oint_{|z-z_0|=R} \frac{|f(z)|}{|z-z_0|^{n+1}} |dz|$$

Now, we use the given inequality $|f(z)| \leq 5|z|^3$. Since $|z - z_0| \leq |z| + |z_0|$, we have

$$|z| \geq |z - z_0| - |z_0| \geq R - |z_0|$$

Thus,

$$|f(z)| \leq 5|z|^3 \leq 5(R + |z_0|)^3$$

Substituting this inequality into the integral, we get

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \frac{n!}{2\pi} \oint_{|z-z_0|=R} \frac{5(R + |z_0|)^3}{|z-z_0|^{n+1}} |dz|$$

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \frac{5n!(R + |z_0|)^3}{2\pi} \oint_{|z-z_0|=R} \frac{1}{|z-z_0|^{n-2}} |dz|$$

Now, let's consider the case when $n > 3$. In this case, the integral converges, and we have

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \frac{5n!(R + |z_0|)^3}{2\pi} \cdot 2\pi R^{n-3}$$

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq 5n!(R + |z_0|)^3 R^{n-3}$$

Since this inequality holds for all $R > 0$, we can take the limit as $R \to \infty$:

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \lim_{R \to \infty} 5n!(R + |z_0|)^3 R^{n-3} = 0$$

This implies that $f^{(n)}(z_0) = 0$ for all $n > 3$ and all $z_0 \in \mathbb{C}$. Thus, $f(z)$ is a polynomial of degree at most $3$.
